title: Open Data in Practice: Open data innovation
displayTitle: Open Data in Practice: Open data innovation
body: Having learnt about the practical side of publishing data, the course turns it's focus to use and innovation. The legal aspects of using open data are addressed before then focussing on opportunities to innovate with open data and build new businesses. By the end, participants will have created a business model for an open data startup.

title: Open Data in Practice: Open data innovation
displayTitle: Open Data in Practice: Open data innovation
body: Having learnt about the practical side of publishing data, the course turns it's focus to innovation. How to businesses innovate using open data? Can you make money from open data? and what does a value proposition based on open data look like? By the end of this course, participants will have discovered the answers to these questions, formed their own business model and practiced their pitch.
instruction: The sessions of the course are briefly described below.

_items.title: Open data value propositions
_items.body:
This session explores the concepts of innovation and value propositions for open data.

We exaplore when companies need to innovate and the key techniques involved. We also look at existing examples of companies that did and did not innovate.

_items.title: Creating a business model
_items.body:
This session takes a practical approach to creating a value proposition and business model around open data.

We explore the business model canvas and look how you can create a balenced business from open data.

_items.title: Managing Open Data Projects
_items.body: Open data is still a developing field and those working within it will encounter a number of common problems. This sessions presents and clarifies the main challenges before examining the future of open data.
_items.title: Perfect pitching
_items.body:
The final session challenges participants to pitch a new innovation with open data.

Communicating the impact of open data is of critical importance, this sessions gives participants practical experience with how to clearly communicate impact and innovation to others.

title: Building the Value Proposition
body: Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Unlike a traditional business where your resources belong only to you and can be protected, open data can be used by others at the same time. To understand how businesses using open data operate, we need to consider the value proposition of open data to a business.
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data that is on the web.

_items.title: What is a value proposition?
_items.body: A value proposition is a credible justification for why your customers will interact with your business in the ways you expect. The core of a value proposition is the problem(s) you solve for your customers. By identifying a problem your customers have and creating a solution to that problem, you create a justification for them to interact with your business.

_items.title: Why are value propositions important?
_items.body: The value proposition of a business is the core of its business model. Without a strong value proposition, a business does not have the justification for operating. The value proposition is also the logic on which the rest of the business is based. If, for example, a business solves a problem for their customers which helps them save money or time, there is a reason to charge for this service. If, however, the problem the business solves is a problem which customers do not value in monetary terms, that business may need to seek alternative sources of revenue. Understanding the value proposition allows the business to anchor their decisions in how customers will interact.

_items.title: The value proposition of open
_items.body: Businesses working in the 'open' area, whether open source software or open data, need to consider the value proposition of the open resources they consume. This consideration is important when developing a value proposition because using someone else's data or software in your business changes the problem you solve.

_items.alt: Creating a value proposition for an open data business
_items.title: Creating a value proposition for an open data business
_items.body: Creating the value proposition for an open data business is different from a traditional business. Where a closed business solves a problem by providing a solution the customer cannot get anywhere else, an open business uses solutions which are already available, in some form, elsewhere. This means that the value proposition for an open business is usually based on being more convenient or cost-effective than the alternatives. Writing a strong value proposition for an open data business means explaining what problem you solve for a customer but also why your solution is better than going directly to the data themselves.

title: Business Value - Case Studies
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: ScholarDream
_items.body:
Scholardream allows parents to find schools for their children and also helps schools run some of their operations in the cloud.

Scholardream brings together performance statistics on schools with availability. The service solves the problem of spending hours hunting for and comparing availble schooling.

_items.title: Batainfo
_items.body:
BataInfo is an application that provides data on films, restaurants, sports, fashion and more. Batainfo consumes data from a variety of differenrt sources and gives users detail about the event like when and where its happening, what it's about and more.

Batainfo solves the problem for customers of having to go to to many different websites to discover entertainment options. By making it simple for customers to get everything in one app, Batainfo saves time and also offers entertainment providers an attractive channel to customers.

_items.title: Agrimark
_items.body: Agrimark connects farmers with the market for their crops. For farmers in Tanzania, often located in rural areas, finding suppliers for crops can be a difficult process. Likewise for hotels, restaurants and other businesses, finding food at the best price is challenging. Agrimark solves both challenges by creating an open marketplace for buyers and sellers of produce.

title: The business model canvas
body:
The business model canvas offers a logical view of any company. It is key to identify any areas of weakness or potential opportunity.

The canvas is formed of nine key boxes, which are divided into three key areas with the value proposition in the middle.

To the left of the value proposition are your activities and partnerships that create that value. On the right are your customers and channels to your customers. Finally, underpinning the whole model are costs and revenue.

A perfect business model canvas should be balenced left to right with a stong foundation in the financial underpinning; it should not be one side heavy.

title: Creating a canvas
body:
There are a number of key pointers that can help you create a business model canvas

1. Stick to the value proposition

Do not expand the scope of your idea in order to fill in any part of the canvas. If you can't fill a box in with your value proposition, then is the value proposition right?

2. Less is more

A maximum of three points in each box is best. Do you want your business to be managing more that 24 different aspects?

3. Pigs don't fly

While innovation is encouraged, creating new categories of customers who will never exist won't help you. The same applies to partners and revenue. Be realistic in all areas of the canvas.

title: Simple licences, easily found
body: Every publisher of open data presents their licences differently.  Here are some examples.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: UK Government
_items.body:
The UK Government uses an Open Government Licence.

This example clearly shows the licence at the top of the webpage, where the dataset is accessed. The licence information is a hyperlink that displays the licence in full.

Have a look at this example dataset and its licence. While you are there, you can also explore all the other datasets and services they offer.
Take me to Data.gov.uk

_items.title: Rwanda Government
_items.body:
The Rwandan Government uses a Creative Commons licence.

This example shows the licence at the bottom of the web page where the datasets are accessed. The licence information is a hyperlink that displays the licence in full.

Have a look at the portal and its licence. While you are there, feel free to explore all the datasets and services they offer.
Take me to Rwanda Stats Data Portal.

_items.title: Tanzania Government
_items.body:
The Tanzanian Government also publishes data which is has an open licence but the licence can be difficult to locate.

The licence is only accessed by clicking on the terms and conditions link at the very bottom of the web page.

Have a look at the portal and its licence. While you are there, feel free to explore all the other datasets and services they offer.
Take me to the Tanzania Open Data Portal

title: Types of licences
body:
The simpler the licence, the better!

There are lots of different licences. To maximise reuse, try to adopt a licence that is already widely used.

Take me to a guide on licensing
title: The eight box canvas
body: Having filled in your value proposition in the middle of the canvas, there are eight other boxes to complete.

_items.title: Key Partners
_items.body: Partners supply you and help you optimise your work. In an open data business, who are your sources of data? who is supplying the most important services to you? Your key partners need to be in close relationship with you to offer high levels of service guarentee.

_items.title: Key Activities
_items.body: What are your key activities that support the business? How much time will you need to support partners, customers, development, marketing and sales of the product?

_items.title: Key Resources
_items.body: Who and what do you need in order to deliver your key activities and value proposition? Do you need to register rights over your products and hold IP? What is the thing that customers are buying?

_items.title: Cost Structure
_items.body: What fixed and variable costs will you have? How much will resources and activities cost?

_items.title: Customer Segments
_items.body: For who are you creating value? Does this segment exist? Can you personally name anyone in each segment? Would they buy your product at the price you are proposing?

_items.title: Customer Relationships
_items.body: What type of relationship will you have with each customer segment? How costly are they? How do you keep them coming back to your product?

_items.title: Channels
_items.body: How will you reach and engage with your customer segments? How do you market, drive purchase, deliver, evaluate and provide care?

_items.title: Revenue Streams
_items.body: How do you make money? What is the cost of the value you are creating? Do your revenue streams relate to channels and relationships?

title: The elevator pitch
body: The idea for the elevator pitch comes from the theory that if you get in the lift of a skyscapper in new york and the CEO of the company is in the lift with you, then you have approximately 90 seconds between the lift doors closing and opening again on the very top floor. Thus you have 90 seconds to potentially change your life forever.

title: Creating a pitch
body: There are two key parts to an elevator pitch, the pain statement and the value proposition.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: The pain statement
_items.body:
Doesn't it frustrate you when....

The pain statement should be short and succint and be designed to instantly catch the attention of your audience. If they are not leaning forward on their chair (metaphorically) by the end of your pain statement, it didn't work.

_items.title: The value proposition
_items.body:
Well I've got a great solution!

This is basically the value proposition from your business model canvas and should be the hook that reals in your catch (the CEO).

title: Picthing tips
body: To help you with your pitching follow the simple guidelines below:

_items.title: Be succint
_items.body:
Keep sentances short. Pause between topics. Focus on the one thing you want remembered.

The Hemminway App can even help score your phrasing.

_items.title: Maintain audience attention
_items.body: Maintain eye contact. Use an open posture. Think about what you would want to hear if it was you being pitched to.

_items.title: No jargon
_items.body: Avoid acronyms. Focus on the problem not the technology that solves it.

_items.title: No questions, only opportunities
_items.body:
Every solution is likely to have issues, avoid them. Don't leave open questions about the issues.

A good trick during a pitch is to leave out one clear business opportunity. If the person you are pitching too then says 'we could also do ...' (mentioning that idea), then say 'great idea, we should work on that'. This gives them ownership and involvement in the product and you have them. This is the hook and line method, you cast your hook and see if they bite.

_items.title: Use lists of three
_items.body:
From a ninty second picth, you are not going to remember much so work with a list of three.

Even better if the list of three focuses on the three areas of the business model canvas, e.g.

This solution:

  1. Solves the customers problem...
  2. Makes better use of partner reslationships...
  3. Increases margin...

_items.title: Repeat key points
_items.body: Repeat your list of three. Each point should be succint, and contain only words the audience understands.

_items.title: Make an emotional connection
_items.body: If you can make both a personal and professional connection, this might help with engagement. Charity videos are good examples of how to make an emotional connection that helps people part with their money.

title: Music to the ears
body:
Q: Why was Steve Jobs so good at pitching?

A: Bacause the pitches had similar structures to popular music

The most famous example of this is the original launch keynote for the iPhone back in 2007:

  • Intro (8 words)
  • Verse 1 (10-7-9 words per sentance)
  • Verse 2 (10-7-9)
  • Chorus (3-2-3)
  • Chorus (3-2-3)
  • Middle 8 (6-4-5)
  • Ending (1-8-4)

A very clever way of making an emotional connection and appealing to our own fondness for music.
